document.title: Ohio’s Learning Standards – Extended with Learning Progressions Science

F3D7C2BBFA494320B63371FA0E39D34A.description:
Engage with items that demonstrate a transfer of energy
(e.g., stretch and release a rubber band, push a toy car,
push on a slinky)to illustrate the change from potential to
kinetic energy.

B2856579DF5040A0B50B73D2F6CB7179.description:
Engage in watching a video that shows how energy is
transferred in ocean waves.

259968B2C6BC4BF2A62452F371B9296C.description:
Recognize movement of a substance as a transfer of
energy (e.g., movement of water in a wave, movement of
a slinky).

AB28054952E940C1B803B316C42E6C2E.description:
Recognize a heat transfer as moving from a warmer object
or region to a cooler one (e.g., touch an ice cube, feel heat
from a heater).

22655FC7F1824D03AD5503BD2110EF56.description:
Model how energy can be transferred in a system (e.g.,
boat on water wave, light from cell phone to eye, turning
on an electrical circuit).

A46155DAE2C14BF1B0241DAC5DAB9263.description:
Transfer
energy in an object
by a force (e.g.,
push or pull).

1BB7F8754D014EDB93F019A24F649E4F.description:
Identify
ways energy can be
transferred (e.g., push
and pull, heat from
hot to cold objects,
light from the sun,
electricity through
wires, etc.).

03D03B1A1A6A4350A5A135F7735A3877.description:
Describe
how some energy
is transferred in
waves (e.g., water,
heat, light).

766D983AE65640B097BA7C9CFFC6C4C2.description:
Energy can be
transferred through a
variety of ways. Mechanical
energy can be transferred
when objects push or
pull on each other over a
distance. Mechanical and
electromagnetic waves
transfer energy when they
interact with matter. Thermal
energy can be transferred
through radiation, convection
and conduction. An electrical
circuit transfers energy from
a source to a device. Note 1:
Energy transfers should be
experiential and observable at
this grade level.

7F4D0BB454B6457CBBD5F5E4613EF55B.description:
Engage with objects that involve energy transformations
(e.g., a flashlight, radio, tv, etc.).

C17096C816AB4B97959DFA4198708627.description:
Actively participate in a demonstration that causes energy
to transform from one form to another.

E5F1F0CFB2EA441CBBDDE5E3501205F4.description:
Recognize the difference between energy transfer (moving
from one location to another as in heat energy from hot
tea moving to an ice cube and melting it) and energy
transformation (changing from one form of energy to
another as in electrical energy from a wall changing to
sound, radiant, and thermal energy in a tv).

185B4CC3DF674CBE84E7E467E0C48984.description:
Given an example, (such as Rube Goldberg device videos
(many are available online)) identify locations where
energy is transferred or transformed.

9B30E1605D994C44A88F9D1689A3161C.description:
Given an electric circuit (or diagram of one), identify
places where energy is transformed from one form to
another (e.g., electricity to light and heat, chemical energy
to electricity).

5BC9A55825584006B36B95C0710BF461.description:
Recognize that the total amount of energy before and after
a change remains the same.

B39E01AA289E4FFE98C76AE18DA2C5BB.description:
Identify
an energy transfer
(e.g., electricity to
light after a lamp is
plugged in).

DCA2B1304CF44BD0B3AE356180CDB7DA.description:
Demonstrate
energy transfer by
completing a circuit
(e.g., switch to
activate a mechanical
item).

1A850D3F9DC94116ABEB3403D0D770AB.description:
Describe
what happens
to an object as it
transfers energy
elsewhere (e.g.,
toy car slows down
going uphill as
energy changes
from kinetic to
potential).

E87302E2BC5A429CA9CEFB71EF3E12F1.description:
Energy can be
transformed or transferred but
is never lost. When energy is
transferred from one system
to another, the quantity of
energy before transfer equals
the quantity of energy after
transfer. When energy is
transformed from one form to
another, the total amount of
energy remains the same.

C4134CD2B8524AEDBE3EE96258C8B765.description:
Engage with different mixtures (e.g., rocks and sand,
different candies in a bowl).

44941A59521E4D21A6607DD16676B4B7.description:
Create a mixture (e.g., water and salt, water and sugar,
salt and pepper).

CD26CC87DBDA4053B814FF11F971CC2D.description:
Identify the mass of components before and after a
change (mixing two substances together (rocks and
sand)).

4D91B5462267491C87B1FF3FCEAC5334.description:
Recognize that the same atoms are present before and
after a change, they are just rearranged.

60C9C3F8379F425BB64CF2B30A137750.description:
Predict the mass of a substance after a chemical reaction
(e.g., baking soda and vinegar in a sealed baggie) or after
a mixture is produced. (Note: This is great illustration that
gas has mass because the mass should stay the same
but baggie will expand. For demonstration purposes, this
is a closed system).

9BAD05B82A084BE092BD75C20A4372A2.description:
Identify
the components of
a given mixture.

F01D6AB7D80D45FB923A7160F294F9E7.description:
Identify at
least one difference
between a mixture
and a compound
(e.g., mixtures can be
separated by physical
processes).

A358F95A358842E8A1DB34B7608D4483.description:
Explain
that the mass
and number of
atoms remains
the same after
being combined
in a mixture or a
compound.

FCCF180187484285B0415007BB20A042.description:
Matter can be
separated or changed, but in
a closed system, the number
and types of atoms remains
constant. When substances
interact and form new
substances, the properties of
the new substances may be
very different from those of
the original substances, but
the amount of mass does not
change. Physically combining
two or more substances
forms a mixture, which can be
separated through physical
processes. Note: Under these
standards, classifying specific
changes as chemical or
physical is not appropriate.

79BA651D20034FA5B70B46C955FA0402.description:
Engage with materials that would be found on the Periodic
Table of Elements (e.g., silver or gold jewelry, iron, helium
in balloons, carbon-graphite, etc.)

9F5AF89FD69F44D1BFA312D8F95DD96C.description: Engage with a picture based Periodic Table of Elements.

4868583B9209430CB04A94442557374D.description: Recognize the Periodic Table of Elements.

499E20CE2C5348E3A7E5B848CC5B4D84.description:
Choose a method to sort a set of objects (candy, toys,
shoes) and describe how they were sorted (by color, size,
type of sole).

B8571F4842CD4A1B8C2D56B36B718941.description: Recognize that elements can be sorted by their properties.

BA4DACC659224880B93642CD9ABE4F3E.description:
Identify common properties of metals (e.g., luster, color,
conductivity).

FABC2C99C2A7495DB1EFCA59B997F795.description:
Given a group of elements, identify them as metals or
nonmetals.

55D8FF5E55C444E6AB077E834E5730A3.description:
Identify
common elements
(e.g., oxygen,
hydrogen, iron,
helium, calcium,
carbon) found on
the Periodic Table
of Elements.

49AA144618924F9C9FFD4AAA737743B8.description:
Identify
an element on the
Periodic Table of
Elements based on
its properties (e.g.,
metal, non-metal, and
gases).

D17AA966B7F24D319506A481A644BC56.description:
Sort
common elements
found on the
periodic table by
properties (e.g.,
metals, nonmetals,
gases).

BD48498A3B064179A954368DDC109461.description:
Elements can be
organized by properties.
Elements can be classified
as metals, non-metals,
and metalloids, and can
be organized by similar
properties such as color,
solubility, hardness, density,
conductivity, melting point and
boiling point, viscosity, and
malleability. Note 1: This is
the conceptual introduction
of the Periodic Table of
Elements and should be
limited to classifications based
on observable properties; it
should not include the names
of the families.

DAA6D663D6E240D59347B5AEEF0470F5.description:
Engage with pictures of various organisms (plants and
animals) in their environment.

2BBE9AC520B34B96BA55786DA71A9F9A.description:
Identify common plants and animals found in a picture of a
given biome.

C54C1B9C46724C9FB673E43BE5CF4853.description:
Based on picture cues, identify general temperature
conditions in a biome.

07A7B7E6EDAF4BD0B5386EDE93896A12.description:
Identify pictures as biotic (plant and animals) or abiotic
factors (soil, air, water).

65C8DCCD6C0A4B5B9036B2577D8C1AD9.description:
Using pictures of various biomes, identify abiotic and biotic
factors in the biome.

D00E87E25F184C52849ABA608114F9E8.description:
Given a specific biome and organism, identify biotic or
abiotic factors that the organism relies on for survival.

3BE484ADE8124506BA2E7F3C106F101F.description:
Match pictures of plants and animals to biomes that are
suitable habitats.

145923942D9842E8BB034188119FCA5D.description:
Given a specific organism, build a model of an ecosystem
to represent their biome.

DA64063FE05743D8BE8333390BE00D2B.description:
Given a specific environment, alter one component and
predict the how that environment will be impacted (e.g.,
a disease wipes out a species of tree, drought, invasive
species).

39E0ADACBF164B359ECBFA97636769DE.description:
Identify
an ecosystem or a
biome.

48C88D8582C045B9AA6ABAE0ECCA2539.description:
Match a
given ecosystem/
biome with its
characteristics.

8B140D0A20EB4031A56313FA5D05B35C.description:
Provide
examples of
how a plant/
animal population
changes in relation
to the availability of
certain resources
and characteristics
of a given biome.

7F13DD5C6F7E431194215536FC79BCEA.description:
In any particular
biome, the number, growth,
and survival of organisms
and populations depend on
biotic and abiotic factors. The
variety of physical (abiotic)
conditions that exists on
Earth gives rise to diverse
environments (biomes) and
allows for the existence of
a wide variety of organisms
(biodiversity). Biomes
are regional ecosystems
characterized by distinct
types of organisms that have
developed under specific
soil and climatic conditions.
Ecosystems are dynamic in
nature; the number and types
of species fluctuate over time.
Disruptions, deliberate or
inadvertent, to the physical
(abiotic) or biological (biotic)
components of an ecosystem
impact the composition of an
ecosystem.

D277D14C75FD405481DB135C71EBABF6.description:
Engage with pictures of various organisms (plants and
animals).

6B38BD575C514F8A900508EAAA144626.description:
Engage in following a path of energy on a food web (e.g.,
trace arrows on a food chain).

340A826CA7DF43A0877B1866A073D283.description: Identify the energy source for plants.

2BB58F57010F49F48DBD66B90992DFCE.description:
Identify that light is needed for plants to perform
photosynthesis to make food.

A7CBB151D47548A88F176AECF492B85C.description:
Identify how humans and other animals obtain energy
(eating).

B5D3F440A7004E5D88866FC107B2CB8D.description:
Given a food web, identify producers and consumers and
show how they depend upon one another.

B30BBEB2C5C74C69A8957198D0051BF6.description:
Trace how energy is transferred from one organism to
another (start with the sun).

ECC8239E5B3C4902B99B2063CEC3CB1A.description: Recognize that animals depend on plants for oxygen.

1CAF55C1C21849F58B379FF361D13530.description:
Recognize that plants depend on carbon dioxide for
photosynthesis.

8F5E53FCF58D404CBF5C77DACCD39403.description:
Recognize that the sun provides energy for living things
on Earth.

78DCA920E6A647569FAB21A3CE7F99FE.description:
Recognize that the energy from the sun flows through
each trophic level (energy pyramid).

6853B0C8D58445D5B3F20BD318E49D59.description:
Identify
that plants use light
energy to make
their own food
(photosynthesis)
and humans and
animals consume
other organisms to
get energy

11F993E54BE84B82BB4B95CAC95493FA.description:
Trace the
path of oxygen
between plants and
animals (e.g., plants
create oxygen during
photosynthesis and
animals breathe in
oxygen to produce
carbon dioxide).

C4EA6A5158E74575BE7003D7F84B1F74.description:
Demonstrate the
flow of energy
from plants to
consumers (e.g.,
energy pyramid).

A4A167D9C398406E94EF0D51D5D1E9E6.description:
Energy flows and matter is
transferred continuously from one
organism to another and between
organisms and their physical
environments. Plants use the
energy in light to make sugars
out of carbon dioxide and water
(photosynthesis). These materials
can be used or stored for later
use. Organisms that eat plants
break down plant structures to
release the energy and produce
the materials needed to survive.
The organism may then be
consumed by other organisms
for materials and energy. Energy
can transform from one form to
another in living things. Animals
get energy from oxidizing food,
releasing some of its energy as
heat. The total amount of matter
and energy remains constant,
even though its form and location
change. Note: Chemical reactions
in terms of subatomic structures
of atoms are not appropriate
at this grade level. Chemical
reactions are presented as
the rearrangement of atoms in
molecules.

B5E3720D1B9443A9A940EB7ADA0620CC.description: Engage with a model of Earth and light (sun).

BFF7993CC18C47F6977C24B83F7ED6CE.description:
Model the sun shining on the Earth. Show the tilt of the
Earth causes seasons (tilt toward the sun is summer, tilt
away from the sun is winter).

F16CEA6432A54072829657DBCE3BC9DB.description:
Track and record temperature data for a year to recognize
temperature ranges for each season.

4A04FA94CC9C416298C66198C8CBBB1F.description:
Use data of temperatures to show how the temperature
changes season-to-season.

2609B1F9620D47EEA642D69FB5DFF056.description:
Track and record sunrise and sunset times to observe how
daylight hours change by season.

D9B6174B7E9D4297AE20BA71E14715FD.description:
Recognize the connection between temperature data for
a season andto the amount of sunlight received in that
season (e.g., longer daylight hours in the summer versus
the winter).

F263F5DAB575445897FABCDA8D4FF582.description:
Compare the temperature of a thermometer when a
light is shining straight down on a thermometer, to the
temperature when you shine the same light from the
side, and relate this to the temperature ranges at different
locations on Earth.

CA350E9D7B19432EB7E203A271469AD3.description:
Recognize that the
Earth is tilted.

0C054F267B784DCAB045AD4F62864C51.description:
Model
the tilt of the Earth
towards or away from
the sun.

A7BFD2A0D0134951B3F2A19376EB5727.description:
Compare the
amount of direct
sunlight on Earth
as it tilts toward or
away from the sun,
and show how that
relates to summer
and winter season.

3C64CDFB3654442F8C313E5F8FF7E1C1.description:
The relative positions
of Earth and the sun cause
patterns we call seasons.
Earth’s axis is tilted at an
angle of 23.5°. This tilt, along
with Earth’s revolution around
the sun, affects the amount of
direct sunlight that the Earth
receives in a single day and
throughout the year. The
average daily temperature is
related to the amount of direct
sunlight received.

92F89B816BD7435782B97CF4F184FCF9.description:
Engage in various visual representations of moon phases
(e.g., time lapse video, a moon lamp).

6E0251263EEA48BAAFECEC748BF6E636.description:
Trace the motion of the moon around Earth on a drawing
or diagram.

8FEF70828270465B919AD2C88A2AF612.description:
Trace the changes in the lit portion of the moon as it
goes through one cycle (i.e. lit portion increases then
decreases).

3A09B8C6B3674891BA2D0F6CD0163A32.description:
Match phases of the moon (as seen from Earth) with a
visual representation of the positions of the Earth, moon,
and sun.

B855DEC8D28E4D58BC53F17198B0AD88.description:
Engage with models of the Earth, moon, and Sun (a light),
to create shadows on both the Earth and moon.

1C94FEC9FB9E4C9D980B9A6EA8DAD07F.description:
Observe pictures of solar and lunar eclipses and line
up models of Earth, moon and sun in the alignment
that would cause the eclipse (can match pictures of the
alignments).

08DEC2D4969249BDA9E7A72BDA32D18F.description:
Engage with visuals of ocean tides on a time lapse video
over a certain period of time (day, month, or season).

B4737B5516954F46B4B68E9916D12D3C.description:
Given a tide table, identify the pattern (amount of time)
that occurs between high and low tide and high tide to
next high tide.

DA130ACCC985418FBA2B04A57ABB4955.description:
Using a model, recognize the position of the moon relative
to Earth during a high or low tide.

275FDAA81EEF4C0BA5F464F41ABE4B2D.description:
Recognize that the
moon orbits around
the Earth.

D2A5C52E316D48CFBEA617BD44156476.description:
Recognize
different stages in the
lunar cycle (e.g., full
moon, new moon).

A79D397785AA46ED93D1610CEFC5F7FB.description:
Show
how the positions
of the Earth, the
moon, and the
sun cause tides
and phases of the
moon.

C5863414424445B7945FC140E8F26ACA.description:
The relative patterns
of motion and positions of
Earth, moon, and sun cause
solar and lunar eclipses, tides,
and phases of the moon. The
moon’s orbit and its change of
position relative to Earth and
sun result in different parts of
the moon being visible from
Earth (phases of the moon).
A solar eclipse is when Earth
moves into the shadow of the
moon (during a new moon).
A lunar eclipse is when the
moon moves into the shadow
of Earth (during a full moon).
Gravitational force between
Earth and the moon causes
daily oceanic tides. When the
gravitational forces from the
sun and moon align (at new
and full moons), spring tides
occur. When the gravitational
forces of the sun and moon
are perpendicular (at first and
last quarter moons), neap
tides occur.

BFA15558CB41401C92430DF3EE2B260C.description:
Engage with models depicting the different layers of
atmosphere.

6E358109CF6C4158B13ADD13DD6BF48E.description:
Recognize the atmosphere as the invisible gas that
surrounds us..

E8AECAF2DD654DDFB075F44CCF883B8F.description: Recognize that the atmosphere is made of gases.

0C60B55617864EFA99DB1DC7660B7EFF.description:
Engage with models depicting the different layers of
atmosphere.

EA0E9F3EF96C4E00A4AF0F729FDF082B.description:
Recognize that temperature changes in each layer of the
atmosphere.

1201704F47B1429A9FDB3412E92D349B.description:
Given a visual representation or diagram, identify a gas
found in the atmosphere.

EA5E2D847C96477A8015C630F08D5EB0.description:
Identify how the gases in the atmosphere are important
for living things (e.g., oxygen for respiration, nitrogen for
plants, carbon dioxide for photosynthesis).

5033A7469DE24858B96DCDD95BB58CE5.description:
Identify pictures from a set that represent pollution to the
atmosphere (e.g., human activities--factories, plowing,
cars; natural events--volcanoes, dust storms, wildfires).

E33402C152FD40E191B5A1E91CEF11B5.description:
Recognize that humans impact the composition of the
atmosphere (e.g., pollution can add too much carbon).

73CC101B95414ECCA08423C64821641B.description:
Identify
the atmosphere as
the air around us.

CC2D9F9AC7E645BC915FC1A795B9E9AC.description:
Identify a
gas that is naturally
present in our
atmosphere (e.g.,
oxygen, nitrogen).

B4180E2155E64932AA59B5074DDC1710.description:
Recognize that
natural events
and human
activities can
cause changes
in the Earth’s
atmosphere (e.g.,
by adding pollution
to the atmosphere
or depleting
valuable gases).

B7111171FAF34FABBAD13017D793DA22.description:
The atmosphere has
different properties at different
elevations and contains a
mixture of gases that cycle
through the lithosphere,
biosphere, hydrosphere, and
atmosphere. The atmosphere
is held to Earth by the force
of gravity. There are defined
layers of the atmosphere that
have specific properties, such
as temperature, chemical
composition, and physical
characteristics. Gases in the
atmosphere include nitrogen,
oxygen, water vapor, carbon
dioxide, and other trace
gases. Biogeochemical
cycles illustrate the
movement of specific
elements or molecules
(such as carbon or nitrogen)
through the lithosphere,
biosphere, hydrosphere,
and atmosphere. Note: The
emphasis is on why the
atmosphere has defined
layers, not on naming the
layers.

8739C2EF1CC44BAE9057F805E0548EA0.description:
Engage with models that show how air or water can move
(e.g., can heat one side of a pan of water and place a drop
food coloring into the pan and watch how it moves).

F8519EBFAD31497BB389EFF6A13902F7.description:
Engage with maps illustrating global wind or ocean
currents.

45EB9120A4C7411A85573FBC304A301C.description:
Observe and record the direction the wind blows each day
to determine patterns (e.g., notice that it should blows in
the same direction (from the west in Ohio) most days (can
watch a flag outside the window)).

BD5396FD9FD44259BA374BA62D5ED791.description: Recognize wind patterns across the United States.

8ADE1B9B23BE4756876CC8DEB3667494.description:
Recognize the sun as a source of energy or heat that can
move air and water on Earth.

1197810B74474564B847C4E24AF18A43.description:
Identify the movement of air and water as convection
currents.

3DA3AA01E2C543D19F8C4BEA9810B857.description:
Recognize that adding or taking away heat can cause
particles of matter to speed up or slow down.

B816D2D7F9BE4D4EBD73EC614BAD4D0D.description:
Predict the type of weather and climate an area may have
based on atmospheric and/or oceanic currents (e.g., show
the jet stream bringing rainy weather from the western
U.S. on a map and predict what weather Ohio will receive,
show warm or cold ocean currents on a map and predict
what kind of climate an area has--Why does eastern
United States usually have warmer climate?).

FC7D1F858D8641F391E8653CDCD73727.description:
Identify
how temperature
causes air and
water to move.

B69B2DBCDB4D41689AD7404D2937E44E.description:
Identify that
air and water move
due to currents.

C590D8437322441D8957D1DE287B6ED9.description:
Describe how
thermal energy
affects ocean
and atmospheric
currents.

0FD0B8819EFC42C7889D7560A6068B08.description:
Thermal-energy
transfers in the ocean and
the atmosphere contribute
to the formation of currents,
which influence global climate
patterns. The sun is the major
source of energy for wind, air,
and ocean currents and the
hydrologic cycle. As thermal
energy transfers occur in
the atmosphere and ocean,
currents form. Large bodies of
water can influence weather
and climate. The jet stream is
an example of an atmospheric
current and the Gulf Stream
is an example of an oceanic
current. Ocean currents are
influenced by factors other
than thermal energy, such as
water density, mineral content
(such as salinity), ocean
floor topography, and Earth’s
rotation. All of these factors
delineate global climate
patterns on Earth.

2E7A32F0C03E41CC9C5B3431A78591AB.description:
Engage with a sealed terrarium or other model to observe
the behavior of water (water cycle)

3CE20705C0F043D88D9F4BB78AA8AE83.description:
Actively participate in discussion about what happens to
water, or where water comes from in the water cycle (e.g.,
a dish of water left out for several days seems to have
disappeared, water falls from the sky).

BC35E8025261469BA947FC701F6D2F73.description:
Recognize that water that falls from the sky is
“precipitation”.

1038A51FD15845809F4561F9E72FF822.description:
Match pictures to types of precipitation (rain, snow, sleet,
hail).

68DAF13B79074EB7A67B40A5051B0263.description:
Trace a water molecule through the water cycle starting
with a raindrop (be sure to include surface runoff).

C2A021615CBE4EE5A47B888B7E2A1005.description:
Identify the changing states of water as it moves through
the water cycle.

9738AC3A387A4E2C866F11D385E68885.description:
Recognize that evaporation is caused by an increase in
energy of molecules (can be modeled by applying heat)
that changes liquid water to gas.

E1AD926B526F4DA98010CAF81BF10364.description:
Recognize that condensation is caused by a decrease in
energy of molecules that changes water vapor (gas) to
liquid water.

A0E3F59B206848E08A5AE2E6331D3C84.description:
Recognize that condensation in the sky forms clouds and
different types of clouds can determine weather (e.g.,
dark clouds mean rain, light puffy white clouds mean nice
weather).

5CD7FF7C4D6040E0983843A1F5CF9170.description:
Build
a hydrologic
cycle showing
evaporation,
condensation,
precipitation, and
surface run-off.

E6926A0574EF45938C70AD1C4FAD8914.description:
The hydrologic
cycle illustrates the changing
states of water as it moves
through the lithosphere,
biosphere, hydrosphere,
and atmosphere. Thermal
energy is transferred as water
changes state throughout
the cycle. The cycling of
water in the atmosphere is
an important part of weather
patterns on Earth. The rate at
which water flows through soil
and rock is dependent upon
the porosity and permeability
of the soil or rock.
